I was initially okay with the premise of the Iraq war, but I think that the repercussions of the 9/11 attacks were still very much lingering, and we went to war in Iraq under a pretext, with many indications that we had already been moving towards Iraq. I believe the Bush administration at the time tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and claimed that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven to be false. That really got under my skin, and overall, the Iraq war has been a real sore spot for me. 

I think the Bush administration was very openly lying to the American people and still hasn't owned up to it. Even Colin Powell has come out and said that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he presented it at the UN. To me, that's a serious malfeasance in office, and I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since at least the 9/11 attacks. They came into office with the intention of going to war, I believe. 

That last part, I forget the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was likely fired from his office. It seems to me that the younger Bush came in with a bloodlust feeling towards Saddam Hussein due to his dad's administration, and I think he was hoping to expand our energy supply in the long run, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. 

Well, I think it's gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there's a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not entirely sure that's a good idea either because I think in the long term it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major issue. 

As it stands, the interim government is dissolving, and from the news reports, I've heard that the Iraqi Parliament is not very effective at all. The Prime Minister doesn't really have control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we're still dealing with these fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I was initially okay with the premise of the Iraq war, but I think that the repercussions of the 9/11 attacks were still very much lingering, and we went to war in Iraq under a pretext, with many indications that we had already been moving towards Iraq. I believe the Bush administration at the time tied the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, and claimed that Saddam Hussein possessed weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven to be false. That really got under my skin, and overall, the Iraq war has been a real sore spot for me. 

I think the Bush administration was very openly lying to the American people and still hasn't owned up to it. Even Colin Powell has come out and said that he wasn't entirely convinced by the evidence at the time, even when he presented it at the UN. To me, that's a serious malfeasance in office, and I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since at least the 9/11 attacks. They came into office with the intention of going to war, I believe. 

That last part, I forget the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was likely fired from his office. It seems to me that the younger Bush came in with a bloodlust feeling towards Saddam Hussein due to his dad's administration, and I think he was hoping to expand our energy supply in the long run, which is also a very underhanded way to do things. 

Well, I think it's gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there's a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and more people would die as a result. I think the alternative that the UN and the United States are moving towards now seems to be like a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, coming in to try to restore order. But I'm not entirely sure that's a good idea either because I think in the long term it will also cause more problems because Iraq's sovereignty will become a major issue. 

As it stands, the interim government is dissolving, and from the news reports, I've heard that the Iraqi Parliament is not very effective at all. The Prime Minister doesn't really have control over the political process, and even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we're still dealing with these fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.
